worked_examples.problem_text: Many corporate bonds give the issuer the right to call (repurchase) the bonds before maturity at a specified call price. (1) In 3-4 sentences, explain why issuers prefer callable bonds and when they would exercise the call option (e.g., if interest rates fall). (2) In 2-3 sentences, explain why investors demand extra yield for callable bonds compared to non-callable bonds (compensation for call risk and reinvestment risk).

solution_steps.part: Step 1 - Issuer perspective and call option value
solution_steps.prompt: Why do issuers prefer callable bonds and when would they exercise the call?
solution_steps.reasoning: A call option gives the issuer flexibility to refinance debt when market conditions improve. This is valuable because it allows the firm to reduce its cost of capital by replacing expensive debt with cheaper debt. The issuer will exercise when the economic benefit exceeds the call premium.
solution_steps.calculation:
Issuer's perspective:

1. Flexibility value:
   • Callable bond = Non-callable bond + Call option (held by issuer)
   • Issuer values the RIGHT to refinance if conditions improve
   • Call option strike = Call price (typically par + small premium, e.g., 102)

2. When to exercise:
   • Exercise when: PV(remaining bond payments at OLD coupon) > Call price at NEW rates
   • Example: 
     - Original bond: $100m face, 8% coupon, 10 years remaining
     - Market rates fall to 5%
     - Current market value of bond ≈ $123m (high coupon bond in low-rate environment)
     - Call price = $102m (2% call premium)
     - Savings from calling and refinancing = $123m - $102m = $21m in PV terms
   • Rule of thumb: Exercise when market rates fall ~2-3% below coupon (covers call premium + transaction costs)

3. Optimal exercise strategy:
   • Call the bonds and issue new bonds at current lower market rate
   • Reduces annual interest expense from 8% × $100m = $8m to 5% × $100m = $5m
   • Annual savings = $3m
   • PV of savings over remaining 10 years > cost of call premium

4. Credit spread tightening:
   • Exercise can also be triggered if firm's credit spread narrows
   • Original issue: 8% = 4% risk-free + 4% credit spread
   • If credit spread tightens to 2%, even without risk-free rate change:
   • New rate = 4% + 2% = 6%, making refinancing attractive

Conclusion: Issuers prefer callable bonds because they retain flexibility to refinance debt when interest rates fall or credit spreads tighten, reducing their cost of capital. They exercise the call when the present value of remaining bond payments at current market rates exceeds the call price sufficiently to justify the transaction costs.
solution_steps.sanity_check: The call option is more valuable when rate volatility is high (more chance rates will fall), when the bond has long maturity (more future payments to refinance), and when initial credit spreads are wide (more room for spread compression). All these factors make sense economically.

solution_steps.part: Step 2 - Investor perspective and required yield premium
solution_steps.prompt: Why do investors demand higher yield on callable bonds vs non-callable bonds?
solution_steps.reasoning: Investors are SHORT the call option - they have sold this option to the issuer. Options have positive value, so investors must be compensated. The call feature creates asymmetric risk: upside is capped but downside is not, and it creates reinvestment risk when bonds are called away in low-rate environments.
solution_steps.calculation:
Investor's perspective:

1. Short call position:
   • Investor receives: Bond cash flows
   • Investor gives up: Right to receive full bond value in all states
   • When rates fall, issuer calls bond away at call price (e.g., 102)
   • Investor loses the high-coupon bond and must reinvest at NEW lower rates

2. Asymmetric payoff:
   • Upside is CAPPED: If rates fall, investor gets max value = Call price (~102)
     - Cannot benefit from capital gains beyond call price
     - High-coupon bond in low-rate environment would be worth 120+, but investor only gets 102
   • Downside is FULL: If rates rise, bond value falls normally
     - Investor bears full interest rate risk on downside
     - No call protection when it would actually help investor
   • Result: Heads issuer wins (calls when profitable), tails investor loses (stuck with bond when rates rise)

3. Reinvestment risk:
   • When bonds are called (because rates fell), investor receives cash (call price)
   • Must now reinvest in NEW low-rate environment
   • Example:
     - Original bond: 8% coupon, held for income
     - Called after 3 years because rates fell to 5%
     - Investor receives $102 per $100 face, but can only reinvest at 5%
     - Income drops from $8 to $5 per year per $100 invested (37.5% reduction)
     - For income-focused investors (pension funds, retirees), this is costly

4. Required yield premium:
   • Investors demand CALL PREMIUM (extra yield) to compensate for:
     - Value of call option given to issuer
     - Asymmetric risk profile (capped upside, full downside)
     - Reinvestment risk
   • Typical call premium: 25-50 basis points (0.25%-0.50%) for investment grade
   • Higher for high-yield (50-100 bps) due to greater refi probability

5. Quantification example:
   • Non-callable bond yield: 6.0%
   • Comparable callable bond yield: 6.4%
   • Call premium = 40 bps
   • Over 10-year life, this compensates investor for expected losses from call and reinvestment risk

Conclusion: Investors demand higher yield on callable bonds because the call feature benefits the issuer at investors' expense. The call caps price appreciation when rates fall (limiting capital gains), creates reinvestment risk when called away in low-rate environments, and represents an embedded short option position for investors that must be compensated.
solution_steps.sanity_check: Empirically, callable bonds DO trade at higher yields (lower prices) than non-callable bonds with identical characteristics. The call premium typically increases with rate volatility, time to first call date, and the spread between current coupon and current market rates.

key_insights: Callable bonds give issuers a real option to refinance when rates fall or credit spreads tighten, exercising when PV of remaining payments exceeds call price
Investors are short the call option, creating asymmetric payoff: upside capped at call price but downside is full interest rate risk
Call premium (extra yield on callable vs non-callable) compensates investors for: (1) value of embedded option, (2) capped upside, and (3) reinvestment risk
Exercise rule of thumb: Call when market rates fall 2-3% below coupon, covering call premium and transaction costs
Reinvestment risk is particularly costly for income-focused investors who lose high-coupon bonds in low-rate environments and must reinvest at depressed yields
common_mistakes: Saying issuers 'always benefit' from callability without recognizing they pay for it via higher coupon rates upfront
Confusing the call option (issuer's right to repay early) with the put option (investor's right to sell back), which is a different feature
Ignoring the reinvestment risk component - call premium isn't just about option value but also the practical problem of finding new investments when called
Not recognizing the asymmetry: investors face heads-I-lose (called away in good times) and tails-I-lose (stuck with bond in bad times) situation
Forgetting that call premium increases with volatility, time to call, and initial rate levels - it's not a constant markup

(2) In 2-3 sentences, explain why investors demand extra yield for callable bonds compared to non-callable bonds (compensation for call risk and reinvestment risk).

worked_examples.problem_text: A sinking fund requires the issuer to retire a portion of the bond issue each year (e.g., repurchase 5% of the issue annually). (1) In 2-3 sentences, define a sinking fund provision and explain how it works mechanically. (2) In 2-3 sentences each, explain how a sinking fund affects: (a) Default risk - Does it increase or decrease the chance that bondholders ultimately get repaid? Why? (b) Timing of cash outflows - How does it change the issuer's cash flow profile compared to a bullet maturity?

solution_steps.part: Step 1 - Sinking fund mechanics
solution_steps.prompt: How does a sinking fund provision work mechanically?
solution_steps.reasoning: A sinking fund is a form of scheduled debt amortization that forces the issuer to retire debt gradually rather than repaying everything at maturity. This changes the bond's cash flow structure and risk profile.
solution_steps.calculation:
Sinking fund mechanics:

1. Definition:
   • Contractual requirement that issuer retire a FIXED portion of bond issue each year
   • Typical rate: 5-10% of original issue per year
   • Starts after initial grace period (e.g., years 1-3 no sinking fund, years 4-10 have it)

2. How issuer satisfies sinking fund requirement:
   
   Option A - Open market purchase:
   • Buy bonds in secondary market at current market price
   • Retire the purchased bonds (remove from circulation)
   • Advantageous when bonds trade BELOW par (discount bonds)
   • Example: $100m issue, 5% sinking fund, bonds trading at $95
     - Need to retire $5m face value
     - Cost = $5m × 0.95 = $4.75m
     - Savings vs par call = $250k

   Option B - Call at sinking fund price:
   • Call bonds at pre-specified sinking fund price (typically par, $100)
   • Random selection or pro-rata among bondholders
   • Used when bonds trade ABOVE par (premium bonds)
   • Example: $100m issue, 5% sinking fund, bonds trading at $105
     - Need to retire $5m face value
     - Call at par = $5m × 1.00 = $5m
     - Cheaper than buying in market at $5.25m

3. Comparison to bullet maturity:
   
   Bullet maturity bond:
   • Cash flows: Annual coupon C, then C + Principal at maturity
   • Year 1-9: Pay only interest
   • Year 10: Pay interest + full $100m principal

   Sinking fund bond (5% annual, starting year 6):
   • Year 1-5: Pay only interest on full $100m
   • Year 6: Pay interest on $100m + retire $5m → Outstanding = $95m
   • Year 7: Pay interest on $95m + retire $5m → Outstanding = $90m
   • ...
   • Year 10: Pay interest on $75m + retire $75m (balloon payment is only 75% of original)

4. Issuer's choice flexibility:
   • Typically can choose open market purchase OR call
   • Issuer will naturally choose cheaper method
   • Creates optionality that benefits issuer
   • BUT overall effect is to reduce default risk (see Step 2)
solution_steps.sanity_check: Sinking funds are very common in corporate bonds, especially for lower-rated issuers. The mechanism of gradual retirement via cheaper of market purchase or call makes sense - it's a rational structure that reduces credit risk while giving issuer some flexibility.

solution_steps.part: Step 2 - Effect on default risk
solution_steps.prompt: Does sinking fund increase or decrease default risk? Why?
solution_steps.reasoning: Default risk is about whether bondholders ultimately get repaid. Sinking funds generally REDUCE default risk through multiple channels: smaller outstanding balance at maturity, forced demonstration of financial health throughout bond's life, and early detection of problems.
solution_steps.calculation:
How sinking funds affect DEFAULT RISK:

1. Reduced principal at maturity:
   • Key insight: Most defaults occur at MATURITY when large principal payment is due
   • Bullet bond: Full $100m due at maturity → large refinancing/payment risk
   • Sinking fund bond: Only portion remains at maturity
     - Example: 5% annual sinking fund starting year 6
     - Year 10 payment: Only 75% of original principal remains
     - Refinancing risk REDUCED by 25%
   • Smaller maturity obligation → lower probability of default at that critical point

2. Forced demonstration of financial ability:
   • Sinking fund payments occur THROUGHOUT the life of the bond, not just at end
   • Each year, issuer must either:
     a) Generate sufficient cash to buy bonds in market, OR
     b) Have access to capital markets for refinancing
   • This demonstrates continued financial health and market access
   • Early warning system: If issuer struggles to meet sinking fund in year 6, bondholders know there's trouble FOUR YEARS before maturity
   • Contrast with bullet: No forced payments until maturity, problems can accumulate hidden

3. Improved debt service coverage:
   • As principal is gradually retired, interest burden falls
   • Example: $100m bond at 6% coupon
     - Year 1: Interest = $6m on $100m outstanding
     - Year 8: Interest = $4.8m on $80m outstanding (after $20m retired via sinking fund)
   • Reduced interest burden → improved interest coverage ratio
   • More "breathing room" for issuer in later years
   • Lower default probability because debt service is more manageable

4. Reduced refinancing risk:
   • Bullet bond: Must refinance/repay ENTIRE principal at once
   • Sinking fund: Refinances/repays in smaller tranches over time
   • Spreading the refinancing reduces risk of being caught in adverse market conditions
   • Example: 2008-2009 crisis
     - Firms with bullet maturities in 2009 faced frozen credit markets, many defaulted
     - Firms with sinking funds had been gradually reducing debt throughout 2004-2008
     - By 2009, less principal outstanding → easier to handle crisis

5. Empirical evidence:
   • Bonds with sinking funds trade at LOWER yields (higher prices) than similar bonds without
   • Typical reduction: 10-30 bps for investment grade, 30-75 bps for high yield
   • This lower yield reflects reduced default risk as perceived by market

Conclusion: Sinking funds DECREASE default risk by:
• Reducing the principal outstanding at final maturity (smaller balloon payment)
• Forcing periodic demonstration of financial capacity throughout bond life
• Providing early warning signals if issuer struggles
• Gradually reducing debt burden rather than concentrating all refinancing risk at one point

This benefits bondholders through lower default probability and earlier detection of problems.
solution_steps.sanity_check: Sinking funds are required more often for lower-rated issuers precisely because they reduce default risk. The fact that sinking fund bonds trade at lower yields confirms that the market prices in the reduced default risk. All the mechanisms described (smaller maturity payment, forced periodic payments, early warning) make economic sense.

deviation_alert.name: Binary Default - Weighted Average Method
deviation_alert.warning: ✓ Binary default model - weighted average method is correct here
deviation_alert.explanation: For single-period (usually 1-year) bonds with a fixed default probability at maturity, the correct approach is: E[r_D] = p_survive × r_good + p_default × r_bad. This is DIFFERENT from hazard rate models.
checkpoints: Default happens ONLY at maturity (single event)
Calculate return in no-default state
Calculate return in default state
Weight by probabilities: p_good × r_good + p_bad × r_bad

solution_steps.part: Step 3 - Effect on cash flow timing
solution_steps.prompt: How does sinking fund change issuer's cash flow profile compared to bullet maturity?
solution_steps.reasoning: From the issuer's perspective, sinking funds shift cash outflows earlier in the bond's life. This has both costs and benefits - we need to analyze the cash flow implications carefully.
solution_steps.calculation:
Cash flow timing effects:

1. Bullet maturity cash flows:
   • Structure: Pay interest only until maturity, then interest + full principal
   • Example: $100m bond, 6% coupon, 10-year maturity
     - Year 1-9: Pay $6m (interest only)
     - Year 10: Pay $106m (interest + principal)
   • Total cash outflow = $6m × 9 + $106m = $160m undiscounted

2. Sinking fund cash flows:
   • Structure: Pay interest + gradual principal retirement
   • Example: Same $100m bond, 6% coupon, 10-year maturity, 5% sinking fund years 6-10
     - Year 1-5: Pay $6m (interest on $100m)
     - Year 6: Pay $6m interest + $5m principal = $11m → Outstanding = $95m
     - Year 7: Pay $5.7m interest + $5m principal = $10.7m → Outstanding = $90m
     - Year 8: Pay $5.4m interest + $5m principal = $10.4m → Outstanding = $85m
     - Year 9: Pay $5.1m interest + $5m principal = $10.1m → Outstanding = $80m
     - Year 10: Pay $4.8m interest + $80m principal = $84.8m → Outstanding = $0
   • Total cash outflow = $6m × 5 + $11m + $10.7m + $10.4m + $10.1m + $84.8m = $157m undiscounted

3. Present value comparison:
   • Sinking fund actually has SLIGHTLY LOWER total cost in undiscounted terms ($157m vs $160m)
   • Why? Because interest is saved as principal is retired
   • In PV terms (discounting at 6%), they should be approximately equal by construction
   • However, sinking fund shifts cash flows EARLIER in time

4. Key differences for issuer:

   Time profile:
   • Bullet: Low annual payments ($6m) for 9 years, then HUGE spike ($106m) in year 10
   • Sinking fund: Moderate payments ($11m) starting year 6, smaller final payment ($84.8m)
   • Sinking fund SMOOTHS cash flows, reducing year-10 concentration risk

   Liquidity management:
   • Bullet: Can hold minimal cash for 9 years, but must have $106m ready in year 10
   • Sinking fund: Must have steady $5m+ available years 6-10
   • Sinking fund requires better ongoing liquidity management

   Operating flexibility:
   • Bullet: Maximum flexibility years 1-9 (low cash drain), but constrained in year 10
   • Sinking fund: Somewhat constrained years 6-10 (forced payments), but less constrained in year 10
   • Trade-off between early-period flexibility and late-period concentration risk

5. When is each preferable?

   Bullet maturity preferred by issuers when:
   • Strong cash flows expected in future (can handle large maturity payment)
   • Want maximum flexibility in early/middle years
   • Confident in refinancing ability
   • Growth firm that needs cash for investment now

   Sinking fund preferred/required when:
   • Lenders want reduced default risk (covenant requirement)
   • Uncertain cash flows → benefit from spreading payments
   • Limited refinancing access → better to pay down gradually
   • Lower credit quality → need to demonstrate ongoing viability

Conclusion: Sinking funds change cash flow profile by:
• Increasing required outflows in middle years (starting when sinking fund kicks in)
• Reducing the concentration of cash outflow at final maturity
• Smoothing the payment schedule over time
• Reducing flexibility in middle years but providing more certainty about manageable final payment

This is generally a COST to issuers (prefer flexibility) but a BENEFIT to bondholders (prefer reduced refinancing risk), hence sinking funds are often demanded by lenders for lower-rated credits.
solution_steps.sanity_check: The cash flow analysis makes sense: sinking funds accelerate principal repayment, which reduces total interest paid but requires earlier access to cash. The trade-off between early flexibility and late refinancing risk is real, which is why sinking funds are more common for riskier issuers where the refinancing risk reduction is more valuable.

key_insights: Sinking funds mechanically require gradual bond retirement through cheaper of open market purchases or calls at par, starting after initial grace period

Sinking funds REDUCE default risk by: shrinking maturity balloon payment, forcing periodic demonstration of financial capacity, providing early warning of problems, and spreading refinancing risk over time
From cash flow perspective, sinking funds shift outflows earlier (higher payments in years 6-10) but reduce concentration risk at final maturity
Sinking funds trade off early-period cash flexibility against late-period refinancing risk - more valuable for uncertain cash flows and limited market access
Market prices in reduced default risk: sinking fund bonds trade at 10-75 bps lower yield than comparable bullet bonds, with larger spreads for lower-rated issuers
Issuer choice flexibility (market purchase vs call) provides some offset to the early payment burden, but overall sinking funds benefit bondholders at issuer's expense
common_mistakes: Confusing sinking fund (gradual mandatory retirement) with call provision (issuer's option to retire all bonds) - they are different features with different purposes
Claiming sinking funds increase default risk because they drain cash - this ignores that they reduce the risky concentration at maturity
Not recognizing the issuer's choice flexibility to satisfy sinking fund via market purchase when bonds trade below par
Forgetting that sinking funds reduce total interest payments over bond life because principal outstanding falls - the total cash cost is actually slightly lower
Saying 'sinking funds always benefit issuers' or 'always benefit bondholders' without recognizing the trade-off: bondholders prefer reduced refinancing risk, issuers prefer cash flexibility
Ignoring that sinking fund features are more common and more valuable for lower-rated issuers, where the default risk reduction is most important

worked_examples.problem_text: Give a simple example (numerical or descriptive) of asset substitution where equity holders switch from a safe project to a risky project after debt is in place such that: equity value increases, debt value decreases, and the risky project may even have lower expected value than the safe one. In 3-5 sentences, explain the mechanics of the wealth transfer from bondholders to equity holders and why limited liability encourages this behavior.

solution_steps.part: Step 1 - Construct numerical example of asset substitution
solution_steps.prompt: Create a concrete example where equity prefers risky project with lower total value
solution_steps.reasoning: Asset substitution (also called risk-shifting or bait-and-switch) occurs when equity holders increase firm risk after debt is issued. The key insight is that equity has option-like payoff: max(Assets - Debt, 0). This creates convexity - equity prefers volatility even if it reduces expected firm value.
solution_steps.calculation:
Asset Substitution Example:

Initial situation:
• Firm has $100m of debt outstanding (face value due in 1 year)
• Debt was issued when firm had safe assets
• Risk-free rate = 0% for simplicity

Now equity holders can choose between two projects:

PROJECT SAFE:
• 100% probability of $120m in 1 year
• Expected asset value = $120m
• Risk: None

PROJECT RISKY:
• 50% probability of $180m (good state)
• 50% probability of $80m (bad state)
• Expected asset value = 0.5(180) + 0.5(80) = $130m
• Risk: High volatility

Note: Risky project actually has HIGHER expected value ($130m vs $120m), but we can modify to make it equal or lower to illustrate the point more starkly.

Modified RISKY project (lower expected value):
• 50% probability of $180m
• 50% probability of $60m
• Expected asset value = 0.5(180) + 0.5(60) = $120m (SAME as safe)

Now let's calculate payoffs:

UNDER PROJECT SAFE:
Asset value in 1 year: $120m (certain)
• Debt gets: min($100m, $120m) = $100m (paid in full)
• Equity gets: max($120m - $100m, 0) = $20m

Debt value today: $100m (risk-free, paid in full)
Equity value today: PV($20m) = $20m

UNDER PROJECT RISKY:
Asset value in 1 year: $180m (50%) or $60m (50%)

Good state (50% prob):
• Debt gets: min($100m, $180m) = $100m
• Equity gets: max($180m - $100m, 0) = $80m

Bad state (50% prob):
• Debt gets: min($100m, $60m) = $60m (ONLY $60m remains)
• Equity gets: max($60m - $100m, 0) = $0 (limited liability!)

Expected payoffs:
• Debt gets: 0.5($100m) + 0.5($60m) = $80m
• Equity gets: 0.5($80m) + 0.5($0) = $40m

Debt value today: $80m
Equity value today: $40m
Total firm value: $80m + $40m = $120m (same as Safe project)

COMPARISON:

                   Safe Project    Risky Project    Change
Total firm value:     $120m          $120m           $0
Debt value:           $100m           $80m          -$20m
Equity value:          $20m           $40m          +$20m

EQUITY PREFERS RISKY PROJECT!
• Equity value doubles: $20m → $40m (+100%)
• Debt value falls: $100m → $80m (-20%)
• Total value unchanged: $120m → $120m (0%)

This is PURE WEALTH TRANSFER from debt to equity, with no change in total firm value.

Even more striking example (risky project has LOWER expected value):

RISKY PROJECT (truly value-destroying):
• 50% probability of $180m
• 50% probability of $50m
• Expected value = 0.5(180) + 0.5(50) = $115m (LOWER than $120m safe project)

Payoffs under this risky project:
Good state: Debt = $100m, Equity = $80m
Bad state: Debt = $50m, Equity = $0

Expected payoffs:
• Debt: 0.5(100) + 0.5(50) = $75m
• Equity: 0.5(80) + 0.5(0) = $40m
• Total firm: $75m + $40m = $115m

                   Safe Project    Risky Project    Change
Total firm value:     $120m          $115m          -$5m (destroys value!)
Debt value:           $100m           $75m         -$25m
Equity value:          $20m           $40m         +$20m

Equity STILL prefers risky project, even though it DESTROYS $5m of total firm value!

Why? Because equity captures more of the upside ($80m in good state vs $20m in safe project)
while debt absorbs most of the downside ($50m vs $100m in bad state).
solution_steps.sanity_check: The key is that equity payoff is max(Assets - Debt, 0), which is convex in asset value. Increasing volatility increases the value of this call option, even if it reduces expected asset value. The $20m gain to equity comes from $25m loss to debt, with $5m destroyed in total. This makes economic sense and matches real-world asset substitution behavior.

solution_steps.part: Step 2 - Explain wealth transfer mechanics and role of limited liability
solution_steps.prompt: Why does limited liability enable this wealth transfer and what are the mechanics?
solution_steps.reasoning: Limited liability means equity's downside is capped at zero - they cannot lose more than their investment even if assets are insufficient to pay debt. This creates asymmetric payoff that makes equity behave like a call option, preferring volatility. The wealth transfer occurs because debt absorbs more downside while equity captures more upside.
solution_steps.calculation:
Mechanics of wealth transfer and role of limited liability:

1. EQUITY AS A CALL OPTION:

• With debt face value F = $100m and assets V, equity payoff at maturity is:
  E = max(V - F, 0)

• This is exactly a call option on firm assets with strike price = debt face value

• Call option value INCREASES with underlying asset volatility:
  ∂C/∂σ > 0 (positive vega)

• Therefore, equity value increases when firm switches to riskier assets, even holding expected value constant

2. LIMITED LIABILITY IS CRITICAL:

• Limited liability means: When V < F, equity gets $0 (not negative)

• Without limited liability, equity would be responsible for shortfall:
  E = V - F (could be negative if V < F)
  Example: If V = $60m and F = $100m, equity would owe $40m

• With limited liability, equity simply walks away when V < F:
  E = 0 (not -$40m)

• This asymmetry creates the incentive for risk-shifting

3. HOW THE WEALTH TRANSFER WORKS:

Step 1 - Initial situation (Safe project expected):
• Debt was issued expecting safe project ($120m certain)
• Debt priced as risk-free: value = $100m
• Equity expected to get: $20m

Step 2 - Equity switches to risky project:
• Good state (50%): Assets = $180m
  - Equity gets: $180m - $100m = $80m (huge gain!)
  - Debt gets: $100m (paid in full)

• Bad state (50%): Assets = $60m
  - Equity gets: max($60m - $100m, 0) = $0 (limited liability protects equity)
  - Debt gets: $60m (suffers $40m loss)

Step 3 - Expected values after switch:
• Equity expected value: 0.5($80m) + 0.5($0) = $40m
  → Gain of $40m - $20m = $20m

• Debt expected value: 0.5($100m) + 0.5($60m) = $80m
  → Loss of $100m - $80m = $20m

• Wealth transfer: $20m from debt to equity

4. WHY DEBT LOSES:

• Debt has FIXED UPSIDE but FULL DOWNSIDE:
  - In good state: Gets $100m (can't get more than face value)
  - In bad state: Gets only $60m (absorbs full $40m loss)

• Debt is SHORT a put option:
  - When assets fall below $100m, debt bears all the losses
  - Debt payoff = min(V, F) = F - max(F - V, 0)
  - The max(F - V, 0) term is a put option that debt is short

• Increasing volatility increases value of this put option
  → Debt value falls as volatility rises

5. WHY EQUITY GAINS:

• Equity has LIMITED DOWNSIDE but UNLIMITED UPSIDE:
  - In good state: Gets $80m (captures large upside)
  - In bad state: Gets $0, not -$40m (limited liability protects)

• Equity is LONG a call option:
  - E = max(V - F, 0) is literally a call option
  - Calls benefit from volatility

• The $80m gain in good state is much larger than the $20m equity would get under safe project
• The $0 outcome in bad state is same as the $0 equity would get if assets fell below $100m anyway
• Net effect: Expected equity value rises from $20m to $40m

6. LIMITED LIABILITY ENABLES THE BEHAVIOR:

• If equity had unlimited liability:
  - Bad state loss: -$40m (not $0)
  - Expected equity value: 0.5($80m) + 0.5(-$40m) = $20m
  - Same as under safe project! No incentive to take extra risk

• With limited liability:
  - Bad state loss: $0 (walks away)
  - Expected equity value: 0.5($80m) + 0.5($0) = $40m
  - Strong incentive to take extra risk

• Limited liability creates the asymmetry that makes equity prefer volatility

7. AGENCY CONFLICT:

• This is a classic agency problem between equity and debt

• Equity acts in its own interest (maximize equity value)
  → Chooses risky project

• But this hurts debt holders (who financed the firm expecting safe project)
  → Debt value falls from $100m to $80m

• Total firm value may even fall (if risky project has lower EV)
  → Destroys economic value

• This is why debt covenants often restrict:
  - Asset sales (prevent switching to riskier assets)
  - Investments (limit risky ventures)
  - Mergers (prevent risk profile changes)
  - Leverage increases (prevent priority dilution)

Conclusion summary:

The wealth transfer occurs because equity's limited liability creates a call option payoff structure. By switching to a riskier project, equity increases the value of this option (higher volatility increases call value) while debt bears the cost (short put loses value with higher volatility). The $20m gain to equity comes directly from the $20m (or $25m in value-destroying example) loss to debt. Limited liability is essential because it caps equity's downside at zero, creating the asymmetry that drives risk-shifting incentives. Without limited liability, equity would bear proportional losses and would not prefer excessive volatility.
solution_steps.sanity_check: This explanation aligns with classic corporate finance theory (Jensen-Meckling, Black-Scholes applied to corporate securities). The option analogy is precise: equity literally is a call option when there's a single debt class. The wealth transfer mechanics are correct: debt's capped upside + full downside vs equity's unlimited upside + capped downside creates the conflict. And empirically, we do observe debt covenants restricting asset substitution in the real world, confirming this is a genuine concern.

key_insights: Asset substitution occurs when equity switches to riskier projects after debt is issued, transferring wealth from debt to equity even if total firm value falls
Equity has call option payoff: E = max(Assets - Debt, 0), which is convex in asset value and increases with volatility (positive vega)
Limited liability is critical - it caps equity downside at $0 rather than allowing negative values, creating asymmetric payoff that incentivizes risk-taking
Debt has fixed upside (capped at face value) but bears full downside losses, equivalent to being short a put option that loses value when volatility increases
In numerical example: equity value doubles ($20m → $40m) while debt falls ($100m → $80m), with wealth transfer of $20m and potentially $5m of total value destroyed
This agency conflict is why debt covenants commonly restrict asset sales, risky investments, mergers, and leverage increases - to prevent risk-shifting after debt issuance
common_mistakes: Confusing asset substitution with other agency problems - this is specifically about equity increasing firm risk, not underinvestment or dividend stripping
Not recognizing that limited liability is essential - without it, equity would bear proportional downside and wouldn't prefer excessive risk
Claiming equity always wants more risk - this is only true when leverage is high enough that equity resembles an option; low-leverage firms don't have this issue
Forgetting to show the wealth transfer explicitly - need to demonstrate that equity gains equal or exceed debt losses (with possible total value destruction)
Not explaining the option analogy clearly - equity is literally a call option, debt is bond minus a put, and this drives the risk preference
Ignoring that this problem is why debt covenants exist - restrictions on asset sales and investments are direct responses to asset substitution risk

In 3-5 sentences, explain the mechanics of the wealth transfer from bondholders to equity holders and why limited liability encourages this behavior.

worked_examples.problem_text: HealthySnacks Co. is 80% owned by undiversified founder (most personal wealth in firm), 20% owned by diversified outside shareholders. Firm can choose between Project Safe (NPV = +$5m, very low risk, minimal failure chance) or Project Risky (NPV = +$8m, high risk, 10% catastrophic failure that wipes out firm, 90% very high payoff). Questions: (A) From diversified shareholder perspective, which project is better and why? (B) From founder's perspective, which might they prefer? (C) If bank requires personal guarantees on debt (founder personally liable if firm defaults), how does this affect founder's willingness to choose Risky and why? (D) Suggest one governance mechanism and one compensation mechanism to better align founder with diversified shareholders.

solution_steps.part: Step 1 - Diversified shareholder preference
solution_steps.prompt: Which project do diversified shareholders prefer and why?
solution_steps.reasoning: Diversified shareholders hold HealthySnacks as one of many investments in a broad portfolio. They can diversify away firm-specific risk and therefore only care about systematic (market) risk. NPV calculations using risk-adjusted discount rates already account for systematic risk, so diversified investors simply choose the higher NPV project.
solution_steps.calculation:
Diversified shareholder analysis:

1. Portfolio context:
   • Diversified shareholders own many stocks (say 50-100+ positions)
   • HealthySnacks is small portion of portfolio (perhaps 1-2%)
   • Firm-specific risk (idiosyncratic risk) is diversified away
   • Only systematic (market) risk matters for required return

2. CAPM framework:
   • Required return: r = r_f + β × (r_m - r_f)
   • Project NPV calculated using this risk-adjusted discount rate
   • NPV already incorporates compensation for systematic risk
   • Firm-specific volatility is IRRELEVANT to diversified investor

3. Project comparison from diversified perspective:

   Project Safe:
   • NPV = +$5m
   • Risk: Very low (minimal firm-specific volatility)
   • But risk doesn't matter to diversified investor!
   • Value to diversified shareholder: +$5m

   Project Risky:
   • NPV = +$8m (calculated using appropriate risk-adjusted discount rate)
   • Risk: High firm-specific volatility (10% catastrophic failure)
   • 90% chance: Very high payoff
   • 10% chance: Total wipeout
   • But this volatility is DIVERSIFIABLE!
   • Expected value using appropriate β: +$8m

4. Why firm-specific risk doesn't matter:

   • Suppose diversified shareholder owns 100 stocks
   • If HealthySnacks (1% of portfolio) has 10% wipeout risk:
     - Bad outcome: Lose 1% of portfolio value
     - Good outcome: Large gain on 1% of portfolio
   • This idiosyncratic variation averages out across 100 stocks
   • Some stocks do worse than expected, some better
   • Portfolio return ≈ market return (by diversification)

   • Therefore, diversified investor is compensated ONLY for systematic risk via β
   • NPV of +$8m already reflects appropriate compensation for Project Risky's β
   • The extra firm-specific volatility (10% catastrophe) doesn't require extra return

5. Numerical intuition:

   Project Risky outcomes:
   • 90% probability: Firm value = $V_good (high)
   • 10% probability: Firm value = $0 (total loss)

   Expected value: 0.90 × V_good + 0.10 × 0
   Discount at rate r = r_f + β × MRP
   NPV = +$8m

   For diversified shareholder who owns 20% of firm:
   • Expected payoff = 20% × $8m NPV gain = $1.6m value creation
   • The 10% wipeout risk is pooled with risks across their portfolio
   • They are NOT exposed to catastrophic personal loss (unlike founder)

6. Decision rule for diversified shareholders:

   Max(NPV_Safe, NPV_Risky) = Max($5m, $8m) = $8m

   → Choose Project Risky

   Rationale:
   • Higher risk-adjusted value creation
   • Firm-specific risk is irrelevant (diversified away)
   • The NPV calculation using CAPM already handles systematic risk properly

Conclusion:
Diversified shareholders prefer Project Risky because it has higher NPV (+$8m vs +$5m) using appropriate risk-adjusted discount rates. The 10% catastrophic failure risk is firm-specific (idiosyncratic) risk that diversified investors can eliminate through portfolio diversification, so they don't require extra compensation for it beyond what's already reflected in the β-adjusted discount rate. From their perspective, Project Risky creates $3m more value than Project Safe.
solution_steps.sanity_check: This is standard CAPM logic: diversified investors price only systematic risk. The fact that Project Risky has high total risk (including 10% wipeout) but higher NPV means its systematic risk component is already properly priced into the discount rate. This is why diversified investors can rationally prefer high-volatility projects that undiversified owners would reject.

deviation_alert.name: Project vs Firm Discount Rate
deviation_alert.warning: ⚠️ DEV-3.3.1 - Project discount rate should match PROJECT risk, not firm's overall beta
deviation_alert.explanation: If a project has different systematic risk than the firm, must use project-specific discount rate. Find comparable firms in the project's industry, unlever their betas, and relever to firm's capital structure.
checkpoints: Identify comparable firms in project's industry
Unlever comparable betas: β_U = β_E × [E/(E+D)]
Average unlevered betas across comparables
Relever to OUR firm's capital structure
Use project-specific CAPM: r_project = r_f + β_project × MRP

solution_steps.part: Step 2 - Founder's perspective (undiversified)
solution_steps.prompt: From founder's perspective (80% owner, undiversified), which project might they prefer?
solution_steps.reasoning: The founder has 80% of personal wealth tied to HealthySnacks, so they CANNOT diversify away firm-specific risk. They care about TOTAL RISK (systematic + idiosyncratic), not just systematic risk. The 10% catastrophic failure scenario would wipe out most of the founder's wealth, which may be personally intolerable even though it's acceptable to diversified investors.
solution_steps.calculation:
Founder's perspective (undiversified):

1. Wealth concentration:
   • Founder owns 80% of HealthySnacks
   • This represents 80% of founder's total personal wealth (undiversified)
   • If HealthySnacks succeeds → Founder is wealthy
   • If HealthySnacks fails → Founder loses nearly everything

2. Utility function differences:

   Diversified shareholder:
   • Utility ≈ Expected portfolio return
   • Risk-neutral to firm-specific risk (diversified away)
   • Cares only about systematic risk

   Undiversified founder:
   • Utility = U(Personal wealth)
   • U is concave (risk averse): U''(W) < 0
   • Cares about TOTAL risk (systematic + idiosyncratic)
   • Large losses have disproportionate utility impact

3. Project outcomes from founder's perspective:

   Project Safe:
   • NPV = +$5m → Firm value increases by $5m
   • Founder's 80% share increases by: 0.80 × $5m = $4m
   • Outcome is CERTAIN (very low risk)
   • Founder's wealth: W_current + $4m (certain)
   • Utility: U(W_current + $4m)

   Project Risky:
   • NPV = +$8m expected
   • But this is EXPECTED VALUE over risky outcomes

   Scenario 1 (90% probability): Very high payoff
   • Firm value increases substantially (say +$20m for illustration)
   • Founder's gain: 0.80 × $20m = $16m
   • Founder's wealth: W_current + $16m

   Scenario 2 (10% probability): Catastrophic failure
   • Firm value → $0 (total wipeout)
   • Founder's loss: 0.80 × W_firm (all equity value lost)
   • Founder's wealth: W_current - 0.80 × W_firm ≈ 0.20 × W_current (only 20% outside wealth remains)

   Expected wealth: 0.90 × (W_current + $16m) + 0.10 × (0.20 × W_current)

   But founder cares about UTILITY, not just expected wealth!

4. Risk aversion calculation:

   Suppose founder has risk aversion coefficient γ and power utility: U(W) = W^(1-γ) / (1-γ)

   For moderate risk aversion (γ = 2, reasonable for undiversified founder):

   Project Safe utility:
   E[U] = U(W + $4m)

   Project Risky expected utility:
   E[U] = 0.90 × U(W + $16m) + 0.10 × U(0.20W)

   The 10% catastrophic outcome creates huge utility loss because:
   • U(0.20W) << U(W) due to concavity
   • Large wealth losses hurt more than large gains help (risk aversion)
   • Founder goes from "wealthy" to "nearly broke" in bad state

5. Certainty equivalent comparison:

   Project Safe certainty equivalent:
   CE_Safe = $4m (certain gain)

   Project Risky certainty equivalent (example with γ = 2, W = $10m):
   • Good state (90%): Wealth = $26m → U = -0.0385
   • Bad state (10%): Wealth = $2m → U = -0.5
   • E[U] = 0.90(-0.0385) + 0.10(-0.5) = -0.0847
   • Certainty equivalent: W such that U(W) = -0.0847 → W ≈ $11.8m
   • CE_Risky = $11.8m - $10m = $1.8m

   Comparison: CE_Safe = $4m > CE_Risky = $1.8m

   → Founder prefers Project Safe!

6. Intuition for founder's preference:

   • The $16m gain in good state (90% prob) is nice but doesn't massively change founder's life
     - Goes from "comfortable" to "quite wealthy"
     - Marginal utility of wealth is decreasing

   • The loss in bad state (10% prob) is CATASTROPHIC:
     - Goes from "comfortable" to "nearly broke"
     - Loses 80% of personal wealth
     - This is personally devastating even though only 10% probability

   • For undiversified, risk-averse founder:
     - Downside risk dominates
     - Not worth gambling life savings for extra $3m expected NPV
     - Prefer certain $4m over risky bet with expected $6.4m (= 80% × $8m)

7. Conflict with diversified shareholders:

   • Diversified shareholders want Project Risky (+$8m NPV > +$5m NPV)
   • Founder wants Project Safe (higher utility despite lower NPV)
   • This is AGENCY CONFLICT based on risk preferences
   • Not because founder is wrong or irrational!
     - Founder's preference is RATIONAL given undiversified position
     - But conflicts with diversified shareholders' value maximization

Conclusion:
The founder, being undiversified with 80% of wealth tied to HealthySnacks, likely prefers Project Safe despite its lower NPV. The founder cares about TOTAL RISK including the 10% catastrophic failure scenario, which could wipe out most personal wealth. Even though Project Risky has higher expected value, the extreme downside is personally intolerable due to risk aversion and wealth concentration. From the founder's perspective, the certain $4m gain from Project Safe (80% × $5m) provides better risk-adjusted utility than the risky $6.4m expected gain (80% × $8m) with 10% chance of losing everything. This creates an agency conflict: diversified shareholders want Risky, undiversified founder wants Safe.
solution_steps.sanity_check: This analysis is consistent with entrepreneurial finance literature showing that undiversified founders often make conservative choices that diversified VCs wouldn't make. The utility calculation showing Safe > Risky for risk-averse, undiversified founder is correct. The conflict arises from different risk exposures, not from irrationality.

solution_steps.part: Step 3 - Effect of personal guarantees on debt
solution_steps.prompt: If bank requires personal guarantees (founder personally liable if firm defaults), how does this affect founder's project preference?
solution_steps.reasoning: Personal guarantees remove the limited liability protection for equity. This means if the firm defaults, the founder's personal assets (house, savings, other investments) can be seized to repay creditors. This makes the downside of Project Risky even worse for the founder, further decreasing their willingness to take risk.
solution_steps.calculation:
Effect of personal guarantees:

1. What are personal guarantees?

   Without personal guarantee (standard limited liability):
   • Founder's equity stake is limited liability investment
   • If firm fails, founder loses equity value but NOTHING MORE
   • Personal assets (home, savings, other investments) are PROTECTED
   • Maximum loss = value of equity stake in firm

   With personal guarantee on debt:
   • Founder agrees to be PERSONALLY LIABLE for firm's debt
   • If firm cannot pay debt, creditors can go after founder's personal assets
   • House, savings, retirement accounts can be seized
   • Maximum loss = value of equity stake + personal wealth needed to repay debt

2. Setup:

   Assume HealthySnacks has debt D with face value $50m
   Bank requires founder to personally guarantee this debt

3. Payoffs WITHOUT personal guarantee:

   Project Risky, Bad state (10% probability):
   • Firm assets: $0 (catastrophic failure)
   • Debt owed: $50m
   • Firm default: Creditors seize remaining assets = $0
   • Founder's equity: $0 (limited liability)
   • Founder's personal wealth: W_other (20% outside investments) = preserved
   • Founder's total wealth: 0.20W ≈ $2m in earlier example

4. Payoffs WITH personal guarantee:

   Project Risky, Bad state (10% probability):
   • Firm assets: $0 (catastrophic failure)
   • Debt owed: $50m
   • Firm default: Creditors seize firm assets = $0, but debt not repaid
   • Personal guarantee triggered!
   • Creditors can now seize founder's personal assets to recover shortfall
   • Shortfall = $50m debt - $0 firm assets = $50m
   • Founder must pay $50m from personal wealth

   If founder's total wealth is W_total = $10m:
   • Founder's wealth after default: max(W - $50m, 0) = $0 (bankrupt)
   • OR creditors take everything: $10m, still short $40m
   • Founder is personally bankrupt

   Compare to WITHOUT guarantee:
   • Founder's wealth after default: $2m (20% outside wealth preserved)

5. Change in expected utility:

   WITHOUT personal guarantee:
   • Bad state (10%): Wealth = $2m
   • Good state (90%): Wealth = $26m
   • E[U] already calculated as low due to risk aversion

   WITH personal guarantee:
   • Bad state (10%): Wealth = $0 (bankrupt!) or negative if guarantee exceeds wealth
   • Good state (90%): Wealth = $26m (unchanged)
   • E[U] is now EVEN LOWER!

   Utility calculation (γ = 2, W_0 = $10m):
   • U($0) = lim_{w→0} (-1/w) = -∞ (or very large negative)
   • Even with 10% probability, this dominates utility calculation
   • Certainty equivalent becomes NEGATIVE or very low

6. Effect on project choice:

   Before personal guarantees:
   • Founder already preferred Safe over Risky (due to undiversified risk aversion)
   • But both projects had positive utility

   After personal guarantees:
   • Project Safe: Unchanged (no default risk)
     - Firm succeeds with certainty
     - Debt paid normally
     - Personal guarantee never triggered
     - Founder's preference: SAME

   • Project Risky: Much worse for founder
     - 10% chance: Not only lose equity, but PERSONAL BANKRUPTCY
     - Downside is catastrophically worse
     - Founder's preference: STRONGLY AVOID

   → Personal guarantees make founder even MORE risk-averse
   → Founder's preference for Safe over Risky is AMPLIFIED

7. Alignment effects:

   Purpose of personal guarantees (from creditor perspective):
   • Make equity holder internalize full downside of default
   • Remove limited liability protection that causes risk-shifting
   • Align management incentives with debt holders (not equity holders!)

   Effect on founder behavior:
   • Standard agency problem in leveraged firms: Equity wants more risk (asset substitution)
   • Personal guarantee FLIPS this: Founder wants LESS risk
   • In this case, founder was already too conservative from equity perspective
   • Personal guarantee makes founder even MORE conservative
   • Moves founder FURTHER from diversified shareholders' preferences

   Standard case (highly leveraged firm):
   • Equity normally wants excessive risk (risk-shifting problem)
   • Personal guarantee reduces risk-shifting, aligning equity with debt
   • This is socially beneficial if it prevents value-destroying gambling

   HealthySnacks case (undiversified founder):
   • Founder already wants too little risk (underinvestment problem)
   • Personal guarantee makes this worse
   • Now founder rejects even more positive NPV projects
   • This WORSENS alignment with diversified shareholders

8. Numerical example:

   Founder's certainty equivalents:
   
   NO personal guarantee:
   • CE(Safe) = $4m
   • CE(Risky) = $1.8m
   • Founder chooses Safe

   WITH personal guarantee:
   • CE(Safe) = $4m (unchanged)
   • CE(Risky) ≈ -$2m (negative! 10% bankruptcy risk dominates)
   • Founder STRONGLY chooses Safe
   • Might even reject Safe if it had any default risk

Conclusion:
Personal guarantees effectively remove the founder's limited liability, making them personally liable for firm debt up to their personal wealth. This makes the 10% catastrophic failure scenario under Project Risky even more devastating - the founder faces not just loss of equity but potential personal bankruptcy. This makes the founder LESS willing to choose Project Risky, amplifying their preference for Project Safe. 

In typical corporate finance settings, personal guarantees help REDUCE risk-shifting by making equity holders internalize default costs, aligning them with debtholders. However, in HealthySnacks' case where the founder is already overly conservative due to undiversified wealth, personal guarantees WORSEN the alignment problem by moving the founder even further from diversified shareholders' value-maximizing preference for Project Risky. The guarantees align the founder with creditors but misalign them with equity investors.
solution_steps.sanity_check: The analysis is correct: personal guarantees remove limited liability protection, making bad states much worse for the founder. This intensifies risk aversion and makes Risky project less attractive. The distinction between typical case (guarantees reduce excessive risk-taking) vs this case (guarantees increase already-excessive risk avoidance) is important and correct.

solution_steps.part: Step 4 - Governance and compensation solutions
solution_steps.prompt: Suggest one governance and one compensation mechanism to align founder with diversified shareholders
solution_steps.reasoning: The core problem is that the founder's undiversified position makes them too risk-averse relative to diversified shareholders' optimal risk-taking. Solutions should either: (1) reduce the founder's exposure to firm-specific risk (make them more diversified), or (2) change decision-making power, or (3) alter incentives to reward appropriate risk-taking. We need one governance solution (who decides) and one compensation solution (how to pay).
solution_steps.calculation:
Solution 1 - Governance mechanism: Independent Investment Committee

1. Structure:
   • Establish board-level investment committee with majority independent directors
   • Committee includes:
     - 2-3 independent directors nominated by outside shareholders
     - 1 director nominated by founder
     - External advisor with industry expertise (non-voting)
   • Committee has authority over major capital allocation decisions (>$X threshold)

2. Process for project approval:
   • Management (founder) proposes projects with detailed analysis:
     - NPV calculations using appropriate risk-adjusted discount rate
     - Risk analysis: systematic vs idiosyncratic risk breakdown
     - Sensitivity analysis and downside scenarios
   • Investment committee evaluates using diversified shareholder framework:
     - Primary criterion: Risk-adjusted NPV (CAPM-based discount rate)
     - Downside risk evaluated in portfolio context (diversifiable?)
     - Independent valuation if needed
   • Committee votes on approval (majority required)
   • Founder can propose but cannot unilaterally decide

3. How this mitigates the conflict:

   Before (founder control):
   • Founder's risk aversion leads to rejecting Project Risky
   • Founder chooses Safe ($5m NPV) over Risky ($8m NPV)
   • Loses $3m in value creation

   After (committee decision):
   • Independent directors represent diversified shareholders
   • Committee evaluates: Risky has higher NPV ($8m vs $5m)
   • Diversified perspective: 10% catastrophic risk is diversifiable
   • Committee approves Risky
   • $3m additional value created for all shareholders

4. Key features:
   • Removes founder's personal risk aversion from decision-making
   • Applies objective, value-maximizing criteria
   • Independent directors have fiduciary duty to ALL shareholders (not just founder)
   • Preserves founder's role in operations and strategy
   • Only constrains major capital allocation decisions

5. Additional governance safeguards:
   • Requires independent valuations for large projects
   • Mandates risk analysis showing systematic vs idiosyncratic components
   • Annual review of investment policy and hurdle rates
   • Disclosure to minority shareholders of rejected projects and rationale

6. Potential issues and mitigations:
   • Founder resistance: Structure as protects ALL shareholders, not just minorities
   • Loss of entrepreneurial flexibility: Set high threshold (e.g., only applies to >$10m projects)
   • Independent director expertise: Recruit directors with industry knowledge

Conclusion on governance:
An independent investment committee with majority independent directors representing diversified shareholders removes the founder's undiversified risk aversion from major capital allocation decisions. The committee evaluates projects using risk-adjusted NPV with proper treatment of diversifiable risk, ensuring value-maximizing choices. This directly addresses the problem: Project Risky would be approved by the committee (higher NPV, diversifiable downside risk) even though founder personally prefers Project Safe.

---

Solution 2 - Compensation mechanism: Staged Founder Diversification + Performance Equity

1. Structure:
   
   Phase 1 - Mandatory partial diversification (Years 1-3):
   • Require founder to sell down from 80% to 50% ownership over 3 years
   • Proceeds from secondary sales go to founder personally
   • Founder diversifies wealth into other assets (real estate, index funds, bonds)
   • Outside shareholders or new investors buy the 30% stake

   Example:
   • Year 1: Sell 10% (80% → 70%)
   • Year 2: Sell 10% (70% → 60%)
   • Year 3: Sell 10% (60% → 50%)
   • If firm worth $100m, founder gets $30m cash to diversify

   Phase 2 - Performance-based compensation:
   • Grant founder stock options or restricted stock tied to firm performance
   • Options have 3-5 year vesting, exercise price at current fair value
   • Amount: Replace 15% of sold equity with options on 20% (strike at current)
   • Performance metrics: 
     - Absolute stock price growth
     - ROE or ROIC vs industry benchmarks
     - Successful completion of high-NPV projects

2. How this mitigates the conflict:

   Before (80% undiversified ownership):
   • Founder's wealth: 80% in HealthySnacks, 20% outside
   • Project Risky 10% failure = catastrophic personal loss
   • Founder chooses Safe over Risky

   After staged diversification:
   • Founder's wealth: 50% in HealthySnacks, 50% outside (from sales + prior wealth)
   • Project Risky 10% failure = serious but not catastrophic
     - Before: Lose 80% of wealth → left with 20% = $2m
     - After: Lose 50% of wealth → left with 50% = $5m + $3m from sales = $8m
   • Founder more willing to take appropriate risks

3. Effect on project choice:

   Risk aversion calculation after diversification:
   • Wealth concentration reduced from 80% to 50%
   • Outside wealth increased from $2m to $5m (from secondary sales)

   Project Risky certainty equivalent:
   • Before: CE = $1.8m (worse than Safe $4m)
   • After: CE = $3.5m (still worse than Safe $4m, but closer!)

   With options:
   • Options have convex payoff (like call options)
   • Benefit from upside, limited downside (options just expire worthless)
   • This INCREASES willingness to take risk
   • Options CE: Additional $1.5m from option value with Risky vs Safe
   • Total CE for Risky: $3.5m + $1.5m = $5m
   • Now: Risky CE ($5m) > Safe CE ($4m)

   → Founder now prefers Risky!

4. Why options help:
   • Options have same asymmetric payoff as equity in levered firm
   • But here it's BENEFICIAL: Aligns founder with taking positive NPV risks
   • Upside participation maintains entrepreneurial motivation
   • Downside limited to option value (already partially diversified)

5. Implementation details:
   • Secondary sale at fair value (independent valuation)
   • Lockup period for remaining 50% (3-5 years) to maintain alignment
   • Option grant size calibrated to restore appropriate risk-taking
   • Performance vesting ensures options only pay off if value created
   • Board approval required for secondary sales to ensure fair pricing

6. Additional benefits:
   • Provides liquidity to founder (can diversify wealth)
   • Brings in new equity investors (outside shareholders increase from 20% to 50%)
   • These new shareholders can push for value-maximizing policies
   • Options vest over time, retaining founder commitment
   • Aligns founder with long-term value creation, not just risk avoidance

Conclusion on compensation:
Mandatory staged diversification (selling down from 80% to 50% ownership over 3 years) combined with performance-based option grants aligns the founder's risk preferences with diversified shareholders. By reducing wealth concentration in the firm, the catastrophic downside of Project Risky becomes less personally devastating. Options add convexity to the founder's payoff, encouraging appropriate risk-taking for positive NPV projects. Together, these shift the founder's preferences toward accepting Project Risky despite its 10% failure risk, because the founder is now better diversified and has option-like upside exposure.

---

Summary of Solutions:

Governance: Independent investment committee removes founder's veto over major projects, applies diversified shareholder framework to capital allocation.

Compensation: Staged diversification (80% → 50%) + performance options reduces personal exposure to catastrophic outcomes while maintaining upside participation.

Both mechanisms address the root cause: founder's undiversified position creates excessive risk aversion. Governance fixes the decision process. Compensation fixes the founder's risk exposure. Combining both is optimal.
solution_steps.sanity_check: Both solutions are realistic and used in practice. VCs routinely require independent boards and force founder diversification through secondary sales. Option grants for risk-averse managers are well-documented in compensation literature. The mechanisms correctly address the specific problem: governance changes WHO decides, compensation changes founder's personal risk exposure.

key_insights: Diversified shareholders prefer Project Risky (+$8m NPV) because they can diversify away the 10% catastrophic risk; CAPM-based NPV already compensates for systematic risk, making firm-specific volatility irrelevant
Undiversified founder with 80% wealth concentration prefers Project Safe despite lower NPV ($5m vs $8m) because 10% chance of wiping out 80% of personal wealth is intolerable under risk aversion

Personal guarantees remove limited liability, making catastrophic outcomes even worse for founder (personal bankruptcy vs just losing equity), amplifying preference for Safe and worsening alignment with shareholders

Standard case: personal guarantees reduce risk-shifting and align equity with debt; HealthySnacks case: guarantees worsen underinvestment problem by making already-conservative founder even more risk-averse
Governance solution (independent investment committee) removes founder's personal risk preferences from major capital allocation decisions, applying objective value-maximization criteria

Compensation solution (staged diversification 80%→50% + performance options) reduces founder's catastrophic exposure to firm-specific risk while options provide convexity that encourages appropriate risk-taking
Core insight: agency problem here is UNDERINVESTMENT (founder too risk-averse) not overinvestment (founder too aggressive), opposite of typical leveraged firm case
common_mistakes: Claiming diversified shareholders are wrong to prefer Risky - they're correct given diversification; the conflict arises from different risk exposures, not different rationality
Not explaining WHY founder cares about total risk - need to discuss undiversified wealth concentration (80% in firm) and utility concavity
Confusing personal guarantees with margin calls or other concepts - guarantees specifically make founder personally liable for firm debt beyond equity investment
Saying personal guarantees 'always improve alignment' - they align equity with DEBT, but can worsen alignment with diversified EQUITY when founder is already too conservative
Proposing governance solutions that don't actually change decision-making (e.g., 'advisory board') - need independent directors with actual authority over capital allocation
Suggesting compensation that doesn't reduce founder's risk exposure (e.g., 'pay higher salary') - need diversification or option-like instruments with convexity
Ignoring that staged diversification is KEY - founder needs actual wealth outside the firm to reduce catastrophic exposure, not just different form of compensation within firm
worked_examples.problem_intro: HealthySnacks Co. is 80% owned by undiversified founder (most personal wealth in firm), 20% owned by diversified outside shareholders. Firm can choose between Project Safe (NPV = +$5m, very low risk, minimal failure chance) or Project Risky (NPV = +$8m, high risk, 10% catastrophic failure that wipes out firm, 90% very high payoff). Questions: (A) From diversified shareholder perspective, which project is better and why? (B) From founder's perspective, which might they prefer? (C) If bank requires personal guarantees on debt (founder personally liable if firm defaults), how does this affect founder's willingness to choose Risky and why? (D) Suggest one governance mechanism and one compensation mechanism to better align founder with diversified shareholders.

worked_examples.problem_text: Three corporate contracts contain embedded options: (1) Supply contract - buyer can reduce orders by up to 50% with 10% penalty, (2) Office lease - 10-year term with break clause after 3 years, tenant can exit early paying 6 months rent as penalty, (3) Loan - 5-year term with prepayment option, borrower can repay early with 2% prepayment penalty. Questions: (A) Identify embedded option type (call/put) and option holder for each contract. (B) Explain how embedded options affect contract pricing and risk allocation between parties. (C) Discuss why it's useful to view contracts as portfolios of risk-free bonds, underlying assets, and options.

solution_steps.part: Step 1 - Identify embedded options in each contract
solution_steps.prompt: What type of option (call/put) is embedded in each contract and who holds it?
solution_steps.reasoning: Embedded options give one party the right but not obligation to change contract terms (reduce quantities, exit early, prepay). We need to identify whether each option is better characterized as a call (right to buy/acquire) or put (right to sell/cancel), and which party benefits from this flexibility.
solution_steps.calculation:
Contract 1 - Supply contract with quantity flexibility:

• Contract terms:
  - Buyer commits to purchase certain volume from supplier
  - Buyer has right to reduce orders by up to 50% with 10% penalty on cancelled volume
  - Example: $100m contract, buyer can reduce to $50m by paying 10% × $50m = $5m penalty

• Option identification:
  - Buyer has RIGHT (not obligation) to reduce purchase
  - Buyer can "sell back" or "put" unwanted quantity to supplier
  - This is a PUT OPTION on quantity from buyer's perspective
  - Alternatively: call option on cancellation (right to cancel)

• Option holder: BUYER

• Exercise decision:
  - Buyer exercises (reduces orders) when:
    * Demand falls below contracted volume
    * Market price falls below contract price (can buy elsewhere cheaper)
    * Cost of reducing (10% penalty) < benefit of not taking unwanted goods
  - Example: Demand falls 60%, so need only $40m not $100m
    * Can reduce by 50% to $50m by paying $5m penalty
    * Saves $50m - $5m = $45m vs taking full $100m
    * Exercise option!

• Justification:
  - Buyer gets flexibility/downside protection (typical option characteristic)
  - Supplier bears risk of buyer reducing volume (short the option)

---

Contract 2 - Office lease with break clause:

• Contract terms:
  - 10-year lease commitment
  - Break clause after 3 years: tenant can exit by paying 6 months rent as penalty
  - Example: $10m annual rent, can exit after year 3 by paying $5m

• Option identification:
  - Tenant has RIGHT (not obligation) to terminate lease early
  - Tenant can "put back" the remaining lease obligation to landlord
  - This is a PUT OPTION on the lease from tenant's perspective
  - Alternatively: American-style option exercisable after year 3

• Option holder: TENANT

• Exercise decision:
  - Tenant exercises (breaks lease) when:
    * Business relocates or downsizes
    * Market rents fall significantly (can lease elsewhere cheaper)
    * Space no longer needed
    * Cost of exit (6 months rent) < benefit of cancelling remaining 7 years
  - Example: After 3 years, business shrinks, only need half the space
    * Continuing for 7 years costs: 7 × $10m = $70m
    * Breaking costs: $5m penalty + find cheaper space
    * If savings > $5m penalty, exercise break clause

• Justification:
  - Tenant gets exit flexibility (downside protection if space not needed)
  - Landlord bears occupancy risk (short the option, must re-lease at potentially worse terms)

---

Contract 3 - Loan with prepayment option:

• Contract terms:
  - 5-year term loan
  - Borrower can prepay (repay principal early) with 2% prepayment penalty
  - Example: $100m loan, can prepay by paying $102m (principal + 2% fee)

• Option identification:
  - Borrower has RIGHT (not obligation) to repay principal before maturity
  - Borrower can "call back" the loan (buy back the debt)
  - This is a CALL OPTION on the bond from borrower's perspective
  - Equivalent to callable bond (bond with embedded call)

• Option holder: BORROWER

• Exercise decision:
  - Borrower exercises (prepays) when:
    * Interest rates fall materially (can refinance at lower rate)
    * Credit spread tightens (borrower's credit improves, can borrow cheaper)
    * Excess cash available and opportunity cost of debt is high
    * Benefit of refinancing > 2% prepayment penalty
  - Example: Loan at 8%, 3 years remaining
    * Rates fall to 5%
    * PV of remaining payments at 8%: approx $100m
    * Market value if non-callable: ~$108m (high-coupon bond in low-rate environment)
    * Can prepay at $102m (2% penalty)
    * Savings: $108m - $102m = $6m in PV terms
    * Exercise prepayment!

• Justification:
  - Borrower gets refinancing flexibility (upside if rates fall)
  - Lender bears reinvestment risk (short the call, loses high-coupon asset in low-rate environment)

---

Summary table:

| Contract | Option Type | Option Holder | Underlying | Strike/Penalty |
|----------|-------------|---------------|------------|----------------|
| 1. Supply | Put (quantity) | Buyer | Purchase obligation | 10% of cancelled volume |
| 2. Lease | Put (lease) | Tenant | Lease obligation | 6 months rent |
| 3. Loan | Call (bond) | Borrower | Outstanding loan | 2% of principal |

Key pattern:
• All three options provide FLEXIBILITY to one party
• Option holder can adjust terms when circumstances change
• Counterparty bears risk and must be compensated via higher base price/rate
solution_steps.sanity_check: The option classifications make sense: buyers/tenants with ability to cancel are holding puts (right to 'put back' the obligation), borrowers who can prepay are holding calls (right to 'call back' the debt). The exercise conditions align with option logic - exercise when valuable (demand falls, rates fall, etc.). All three shift risk from option holder to counterparty.

solution_steps.part: Step 2 - Effect on pricing and risk allocation
solution_steps.prompt: How do embedded options affect contract pricing and which party bears which risks?
solution_steps.reasoning: Options have positive value, so the party holding the option must pay for it through higher prices, lower yields, or explicit premiums. The embedded options also shift various risks (quantity, occupancy, reinvestment) from the option holder to the counterparty. We need to analyze both the pricing implications and the risk reallocation.
solution_steps.calculation:
Effect on pricing:

1. General principle - Option value in pricing:

• Law of one price:
  Contract = Risk-free component + Options

• Party holding valuable option must pay for it:
  Higher price, lower yield, explicit premium, or worse contract terms

• Example framework:
  - Call option value = C > 0
  - Party long call pays: Base price + C
  - Party short call receives: Base price + C (compensation for giving up upside)

2. Contract 1 - Supply contract:

• Buyer holds put option (reduce quantity)
• Option has value: V_put > 0

• Pricing implication:
  - Buyer must pay HIGHER unit price than without flexibility
  - Alternative: Pay explicit option premium
  
• Example:
  - Base contract (no flexibility): $100 per unit for firm 1M units → $100m total
  - With put option: $105 per unit for up to 1M units → $105m if take all
  - Buyer pays $5m extra for the flexibility
  - If demand falls and buyer reduces 50%, pays:
    * $105 × 0.5M = $52.5m for goods taken
    * 10% penalty on $52.5m = $5.25m
    * Total: $57.75m vs $100m firm obligation

• Risk allocation:
  - Quantity risk SHIFTS from buyer to supplier
  - Supplier must plan for variable volume:
    * Cannot fully commit capacity
    * Must have flexible production
    * Bears inventory risk if buyer cancels
  - Buyer gets protection against demand shortfall

3. Contract 2 - Office lease:

• Tenant holds put option (break lease early)
• Option has value: V_put > 0

• Pricing implication:
  - Tenant pays HIGHER annual rent than non-cancellable lease
  - Compensation for landlord's reoccupancy risk

• Example:
  - Non-cancellable 10-year lease: $10m per year
  - Cancellable lease (break after year 3 with 6-month penalty): $11m per year
  - Tenant pays $1m extra per year for break flexibility
  - If tenant stays full 10 years, pays $110m vs $100m (10% premium)
  - But if breaks at year 3, total paid: 3 × $11m + $5.5m = $38.5m vs $100m obligation

• Risk allocation:
  - Occupancy risk SHIFTS from tenant to landlord
  - Landlord bears:
    * Re-leasing risk (may take time to find new tenant)
    * Market risk (rents may have fallen)
    * Vacancy costs during search
  - Tenant gets protection against:  
    * Business downturn requiring downsizing
    * Relocation needs
    * Excessive space commitment

4. Contract 3 - Loan with prepayment:

• Borrower holds call option (prepay loan)
• Option has value: V_call > 0

• Pricing implication:
  - Borrower pays HIGHER interest rate than non-callable loan
  - Compensation for lender's reinvestment risk

• Example:
  - Non-callable 5-year loan: 6.0% interest rate
  - Callable loan (prepayable with 2% penalty): 6.5% interest rate
  - Borrower pays 50 bps extra for prepayment flexibility
  - On $100m loan over 5 years, this costs:
    * Extra 0.5% × $100m × 5 years = $2.5m (rough calculation)
  - But if rates fall to 4% and borrower prepays:
    * Saves by refinancing at 4% vs continuing at 6.5%
    * Benefit > $2.5m extra cost + 2% prepayment penalty if rate drop is large enough

• Risk allocation:
  - Interest rate risk and reinvestment risk SHIFT from borrower to lender
  - Lender bears:
    * Reinvestment risk: If loan prepaid when rates low, must reinvest at lower yields
    * Upside cap: Can't benefit from holding high-coupon loan in low-rate environment
  - Borrower gets protection against:
    * Rate decline (can refinance)
    * Credit spread tightening (can refinance at better terms)
    * Cash flow needs (can pay down debt when cash available)

5. General patterns across all three contracts:

• Pricing effect:
  - Option holder pays premium via:
    * Higher unit prices (Contract 1)
    * Higher rent (Contract 2)
    * Higher interest rate (Contract 3)
  - Magnitude of premium depends on option value:
    * Volatility of underlying (demand, rents, interest rates)
    * Time to expiration
    * Current moneyness

• Risk allocation effect:
  - Option = risk transfer mechanism
  - Risk shifts FROM option holder TO counterparty:
    * Quantity risk: Buyer → Supplier
    * Occupancy risk: Tenant → Landlord
    * Reinvestment risk: Borrower → Lender
  
  - Counterparty (short option) absorbs downside scenarios:
    * Supplier: Demand drops, can't sell goods elsewhere
    * Landlord: Tenant leaves, space vacant
    * Lender: Rates fall, must reinvest at low yields

  - Option holder (long option) retains upside:
    * Buyer: If demand is high, still benefits from supply
    * Tenant: If business grows, keeps good location
    * Borrower: If rates rise, keeps low fixed rate

6. Asymmetry of payoffs:

• This is classic option asymmetry:
  - Option holder: Heads I win (exercise), tails I don't lose much (don't exercise)
  - Counterparty: Heads I don't win much (capped upside), tails I lose (absorb downside)

• Example - Loan prepayment:
  - Borrower (long call):
    * Rates fall 3% → Prepay, save big (exercise option)
    * Rates rise 3% → Keep loan at favorable rate (option expires worthless but borrower already has good rate)
  - Lender (short call):
    * Rates fall 3% → Lose high-yielding asset, must reinvest at low rates (hurt by exercise)
    * Rates rise 3% → Stuck with low-yielding asset (no benefit from rates rising)

• This asymmetry is why options have value and why counterparties demand compensation

Conclusion:
Embedded options affect pricing by requiring the option holder to pay a premium (via higher prices, rents, or interest rates) to the counterparty who is short the option. This compensates the counterparty for bearing risks that have been shifted to them: quantity risk for suppliers, occupancy risk for landlords, and reinvestment risk for lenders. The option creates asymmetric payoffs where the holder captures upside from favorable changes (falling demand, relocating, falling rates) while the counterparty absorbs the corresponding downsides. These options are valuable because they provide flexibility to adjust when circumstances change, and the pricing premium reflects this value.
solution_steps.sanity_check: The pricing effects make sense: empirically, cancelable contracts do have higher prices, callable bonds have higher yields, and leases with break clauses have higher rents. The risk allocation is correct - options fundamentally shift risk from holder to writer. The asymmetry explanation captures why options have positive value and why short parties must be compensated.

solution_steps.part: Step 3 - Contracts as portfolios of securities
solution_steps.prompt: Why is it useful to think of contracts as portfolios of bonds, assets, and options?
solution_steps.reasoning: Decomposing contracts into familiar financial securities (bonds, stocks, options) helps us: (1) price contracts more accurately using established models, (2) understand risk exposure clearly, and (3) design hedging strategies. This framework makes implicit options explicit and enables quantitative valuation.
solution_steps.calculation:
Conceptual framework - Contracts as security portfolios:

1. General decomposition:

• Any contract with embedded options can be viewed as:
  Contract = Risk-free bond(s) + Underlying asset + Option(s)

• Components:
  a) Risk-free bond component:
     - Present value of fixed, certain cash flows
     - Base obligations without any flexibility
     - Valued by discounting at risk-free rate

  b) Underlying asset component:
     - Economic value being exchanged (goods, services, space, capital)
     - Valued at market rates

  c) Option component(s):
     - Flexibility to adjust terms
     - Valued using option pricing models (Black-Scholes, binomial, etc.)

2. Contract 1 - Supply contract decomposition:

• Traditional view:
  "Buyer commits to $100m purchase, can reduce by 50% with 10% penalty"

• Portfolio view:
  Supply contract = 
    + Long position in goods (underlying asset worth $100m)
    + Short position in bond (obligation to pay $105m, reflecting option premium)
    + Long put option on 50% of quantity (strike = 90% of contract price)

• More detailed:
  Buyer's position:
  = Receive goods worth $100m at market prices
  - Pay $105m in fixed installments (bond-like obligation)
  + Put option: right to "sell back" up to $50m of goods at 90% of contract price

• Option valuation:
  - Underlying: $50m of goods (spot price S)
  - Strike: $45m (contract price minus 10% penalty)
  - Volatility: σ (demand/price volatility)
  - Maturity: Contract duration T
  - Put value: P = Strike × e^(-rT) × N(-d2) - Spot × N(-d1) (Black-Scholes)

• Pricing the contract:
  - Fair contract price = Spot price + Put option value
  - $105 per unit = $100 market price + $5 option premium
  - Supplier receives $5 premium to compensate for bearing quantity risk

3. Contract 2 - Office lease decomposition:

• Traditional view:
  "10-year lease at $11m per year, break after year 3 with 6-month penalty"

• Portfolio view:
  Lease = 
    + Long position in office space (asset generates rental value)
    + Short position in annuity bond (obligation to pay $11m × 10 years)
    + Long put option to cancel bond after year 3 (strike = 6 months rent)

• More detailed:
  Tenant's position:
  = Use of office space (underlying asset)
  - Annuity bond: pay $11m per year for 10 years = $110m PV
  + American put option exercisable at year 3:
    * Right to cancel remaining 7 years of rent payments
    * Strike price = $5.5m (6 months penalty)
    * Underlying = PV of remaining 7 years at $11m/year = $77m (at inception)

• Option valuation:
  - Underlying: PV(remaining rents) at exercise date
  - Strike: $5.5m (penalty)
  - Volatility: σ (rental rate volatility + occupancy need volatility)
  - Exercise date: Year 3
